subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Improved protocol
author: SnowfireL@aol.com
full_text:
--part1_823e2.59ca710f.396b561f_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Language: en

You mean some big business does, wait until ATT or Verison knows this is  
=
the real deal, can you imagine ?  The cost to talk with a loved one?   It 
=
would ruin what we all have right now.  Of course with all their  millions,=
 
they could afford to spend the money building the perfect tele to the  so=
 
called dead.  sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/11/2010 1:00:36 P.M. Eastern Da=
ylight Time,  
april@... writes:

 
 
 
I fail to =
see a problem with it. Why are you so freaked out Snow?  
Regardless of the=
 outcome, it shouldn't bother you any. We only stand to gain  from 
this.

=
On Sun, Jul 11, 2010 at 10:43 AM, Rj <_rasterer@..._ 
(mailto:rastere=
r@...) >  wrote:


 
 
 
What are your objections Snowfire?  
How can=
 we  improve this?  




--- On Sun, 7/11/10, _SnowfireL@..._ (mailto:S=
nowfireL@...)  
<_SnowfireL@..._ (mailto:SnowfireL@...) > wrote=
:



From: _SnowfireL@..._ (mailto:SnowfireL@...)  <_SnowfireL@aol.=
Sno_ 
(mailto:SnowfireL@...) >

Subject: Re:  [EVP-ITC] Improved protoc=
ol  

To: _EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsEVP-_ (mailto:EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com) 

Date=
:  Sunday, July 11, 2010, 9:40 AM


 
I am sorry now that I got involved in=
 this testing, this is not  a science 
class, and I am sorry list members, =
I was unaware of what  they were up to. 
no wonder David (the tech) did not=
 want to get  involved.  We don't know who 
people are on these  lists to b=
egin with, and I should have been more 
careful,  getting old.  sf
 
 
In a=
 message dated 7/11/2010 11:37:38 A.M. Eastern Daylight  Time, 
rasterer@ya=
hoo. com writes:

 
Your points are well taken John.  And I  agree it is a =
first attempt and 
certainly can be improved on  successive trials, and can=
not determine the 
origin of the  messages.

For this first experiment/prot=
ocol , I  thought we would go as generic as 
possible: it doesn't  matter r=
eally here where the information comes from, or 
how  different people inte=
rpret it: just determine the object in  the 
specific timeframe.  We'll sta=
rt with data on how  accurate the participants can 
get, however they do  i=
t.

As to your comment on the audio files:   originally I considered requir=
ing 
as part of the protocol to  include the audio.  Maybe that is still a =
good  
idea.  The reason I didn't, is because people often  claim to hear d=
ifferent 
things each time they listen to a  file.  Posting a file with an =
incorrect 
answer, for  example, the person may later claim (after the expe=
riment)  to 
NOW hear the right answer.  And others may confirm  it.

This =
seemed liked a rabbit hole, and I'm not sure  how to handle it. So for 
thi=
s trial, I figured we'd just not  go there, and require replies only be 
va=
lid if they are  given during the experiments specified time frame. Once 
t=
he  actual object is know, it seems too easy for a person to  come up with =

the answer.

But yeah, we need to see how  this goes, fix the problems, an=
d come up with 
more of  them!

--- On Sun, 7/11/10, John S  <phenom_invest=
igator @_yahoo.com_ 
(http://yahoo.com/) > wrote:


From:  John S <phenom_i=
nvestigator @_yahoo.com_ (http://yahoo.com/) >
Subject: [EVP-ITC]  Improved=
 protocol  

To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups  .com

Date: Sunday, July 11, 2010, 8:=
08 AM


 
 
 
Since we're talking about experiments and protocols  here are=
 some ideas to 
improve
the protocol RJ suggested initially. Using a test  =
target is one way of 
establishing a 
truth in time, which is the basis of =
this experiment.  But there are a 
couple of issues.
 
It is quite possible=
 that someone could discern the  target through remote 
viewing alone.
This=
 would negate the need for involvement of a  spirit communicator or 
discar=
nate entity.
Outcomes depend on the word of those reporting.  The true skep=
tic (not 
cynic) would 
therefore say that this experiment contains a basic=
  flaw in that it does 
not uniquely 
indicate that the information was obt=
ained in the  prescribed manner. 
Providing access
to the raw audio file wo=
uld not necessarily  constitute proof either, since 
many of these 
communi=
cations can only be heard by certain people,  

If the audio file were quit=
e clear,  timing  becomes an issue. In other 
words, when  was 
the audio a=
ctually recorded?  This issue can be  mitigated simply by 
requiring any
cl=
aimant to email the audio file to a trusted party  before the test ends. 
I=
t would be best 
if the trusted party were not otherwise involved in  the e=
xperiment and it 
was  their duty 
simply to collect the claims. Once all c=
laims  had been collected they 
could be posted 
publicly for review by the=
 community in  general.  The experimenter could 
decide if any 
of the clai=
ms seemed to have hit, and this  decision could be reviewed by 
anyone if d=
esired. 
 
The important detail however is that this experiment  does not c=
ompletely 
answer the 
question. It is a first attempt and certainly can be=
  improved on 
successive trials.
 
Successive trials are always a good ide=
a, since it  provides replication. 
And it would be
best if others replicat=
ed the experiment using a very  similar protocol. If 
these were to
succeed=
, the community could then state that out of X  trials Y had 
succeeded (by=
 
some definition of success) potentially giving a  success rate above that=
 
expected 
by random chance. This would make the outcome  quantifiable and=
 measureable 
and thus meaningful.
 
But also important to note, this would=
 only prove the  potential veracity 
of the messages.
It would not (and can=
not as far as I can tell) prove  the origin of the 
messages. This detail
w=
ill, I fear, remain a matter for belief and  speculation for quite some 
ti=
me to come.
 
 
 


























--part1_823e2.59ca710f.396b561f_boundary
